Variation Example: A poor farmer (beggar, old woman, poor girl, preacher) arrives in heaven at the same time as a rich man (priest, lawyer, townsman, nun, hermit, saint, old couple). The rich man enters first & the poor man outside overhears that he is received with rejoicing. When the farmer enters nothing similar happens. When the farmer complains that things in heaven are handled as partially as on earth, St. Peter explains that poor people come to heaven every day, but a rich man comes only once in a hundred years.
A clergyman sees his good & evil deeds being weighed. He asks them to have his faith in Christ (Virgin Mary) thrown onto the scale. He is saved.
While a good man is yet living on earth, sev eral spendid rooms are prepared for him in heaven (paradise). A dead miser asks the living man to give him at least one of them.

Christ rescues dead people (sinners) from hell but leaves Solomon there to rescue himself. Thereupon Solomon forges the devil (Satan, Lucifer) to a chain, which he gnaws at continuously. Every year, just before Easter, the devil nearly manages to bite through the chain, but it immediately renews itself.

Classifications: St. Peter's Mother Falls from Heaven
Variation Example: St. Peter (other saint) in heaven is allowed to free his mother (sinner, witch, his father, woodcutter; clergyman, thief) from hell (purgatory). When she is pulled to heaven on a rope (stalk) the other inhabitants of the hell (the dead) catch her feet in order to be freed as well. She does not want them to come up & kicks them away. The rope tears & she falls back into hell (St. Peter acknowledges her bad character & casts her out).

An old couple climb up a beanstalk (which grows through the roof of their house) to heaven. The old man climbs carrying his wife in a sack which he holds with his teeth. The old woman keeps asking him, “Is heaven still far away?” When he answers, she falls to earth (her husband reaches heaven). In another variant an old couple who climbed to heaven on a bean stalk promise not to eat bread dough (pie, apples) & not to sit in God’s little carriage. They break their promise (the woman sits in the little carriage, which promptly drives off with her) & they are cast out of heaven.

A person (Solomon, soldier, smith, miller, shoe-maker, Gypsy, farmer, etc.) in hell threatens to build a church (monastery) there. The devil cannot let this happen, so the person is expelled from hell (receives gold as rent, can marry the daughter of a king or a landlord).

In order to pay his drinking debts a man (Nobis) promises himself to the devil. But he payed the devil by taking a beating instead of his soul, so he is not allowed to enter either hell nor heaven. Thereupon he starts to run a tavern (named “Nobiskrug”) between heaven & hell (outside heaven’s gate, outside hell’s gate). In some variants so many people remain at the tavern in front of the entrance to heaven that finally the host is allowed to enter heaven as a preventive measure. Or, many candidates for heaven bring their own drinks from earth (they are already drunk), so that the host has to close his business.
A clergyman assures an old woman that she is not destined for hell because it was made for weeping & gnashing of teeth. She, however, does not have any teeth left any more.

Classifications: Joseph & Mary Threatens to Leave Heaven
Variation Example: St. Peter (God, Christ), the porter of heaven, notices unfamiliar faces among his people. He learns that Joseph had opened the back door for them. When he asks Joseph why he did such a thing, Joseph too becomes angry. He vows that he will not obey St. Peter’s orders & threatens to leave heaven with Mary & the child. St. Peter relents.

Classifications: The Devil & the Angel Fight for the Soul
Variation Example: The devil & an angel quarrel at the deathbed of a rich miser for his soul. Finally the scale tips in his favor because of a stalk (other objects) which the rich man had used to help a beggar. He is granted a place in paradise.

Classifications: The Death of the Good and of the Bad Man
Variation Example: When a good man dies, a bee (his soul) flies out of his mouth. A white & black bird fight over it & the white bird catches it. When a bad man dies, the black bird catches the bee. In an Estonian variant an angel shows a rich man how a good man dies by taking him to a deathbed. Two white doves sit at the head of the bed & two black ravens at the foot. When the man dies the doves fly up & take his soul away. At the deathbed of a bad man, the two ravens sit at the head & the doves are at the foot. When the man dies the ravens take his soul away & the doves cry.

Classifications: Rich Man Allowed to stay in Heaven
Variation Example: Rich Man Allowed to Stay in Heaven because of single deed of charity. (Sometimes he is repaid & sent to hell.)

Classifications: Old Man Repaid for Good Deeds
Variation Example: He helps a beggar (gives him money) to build his house. When he goes there to see it, he finds himself in paradise.

Classifications: The Snares of the Evil One
Variation Example: An unborn child is promised to the devil in a crisis. When some years later the promised child is to be fetched by the devil, he takes refuge in a holy place (church, altar, cemetery) in a magic circle reading the bible (clergyman draws a ring around him). The devil cannot tempt him outside the circle so the contract is voided.

A poor pious man puts his last piece of bread on a tree stump. A young devil steals the bread in order to test him. The pious man blesses the thief. In hell the devil is reprimand ed by Lucifer & ordered to serve the farmer for one (three, seven) year. The devil works to make his master prosperous, punishes an evil landowner, & then returns to hell.

Misc. type. A clergyman (priest, businessman) agrees to give his daughter (soul) to the devil (devils) if the devil is able to build a church (building, castle, palace, bridge, dams, streets) overnight. The clergyman (his wife) makes the rooster crow earlier than usual, & the devils disappear.

Classifications: The Youth Sold to the Devil
Variation Example: When the devil (giant) comes to fetch a youth, his parents sew him up on three successive nights in a dog’s skin, a ram’s skin, & a goat’s skin (they hide him in an ear of corn as a kernel, on a swan’s neck as down, in a flounder as spawn). The devil cannot find him.

Classifications: The Man Promised to the Devil Becomes a Clergyman
Variation Example: He sprinkles holy water on the devils in hell; & tears up the contract his father had once concluded with the devil. He becomes a high priest. He tells a sinner to do penance & later, as bishop, he releases him from his sins.

Classifications: The Boy Promised to Go to the Devil Save Himself by His Good Conduct
Variation Example: A boy is sold to the devil for money (before his birth) by his parents. He is to be handed over at a fixed time (when he is four years old). When the boy learns about his destiny, he decides to manage his fortune on his own. He leaves home & meets the Virgin Mary (another holy person). In gratitude for the boy’s helpful & friendly behavior, Virgin Mary gives him a magic tool (water) by which he can save himself from the devil when he comes to fetch him (he fights the devil & wins).

A man (three starving soldiers) promises himself to the devil (in the shape of a dragon) for money (food). If, at the end of a certain time (seven years), he can solve three (seven) riddles which the devil pro-pounds, he will be released from the contract. The devil has ob jects which appear different from what they really are, & the man must guess their real nature: he-goat – horse, cloth – goat-skin, gold cup – cup of pitch, roasted meat – dead dog, spoon – whale-rib, wineglass – horse’s hoof. Or the devil asks seemingly impossible questions: what is sweet-er than honey, softer than swan’s down, harder than stone? Or he asks for the symbolic meaning of the numbers one to seven (ten, twelve). Or he sets impossible tasks. An old woman (devil’s grandmother) helps the man to solve the riddles. Or he finds the solutions by hiding in a tree & overhearing the devil’s conversation with a companion. Or he is hidden by the devil’s grandmother, who gets the secrets from the devil, or is helped by another being (angel, St. Andrew, Gypsy). Finally the man saves his soul & escapes from the devil.

This misc. type comprises various tales in which someone uses the word devil carelessly, or carelessly utters a curse (e.g. “The devil will get you!”). The curse becomes true & the devil appears (often in disguise, as young man, as dog) & fetches the person who made the curse or who was cursed (often boy, girl, daughter)

A poor man in desparate intends to hang himself in despair. Then he makes a bargain with the devil: If the man does not sleep for three nights, the devil will give him a large sum of money. Whenever the devil asks the man if he is sleeping, the man pretends that he is thinking about something. While the devil verifies the things the man is thinking about, three nights pass & afterwards the man receives the money from the devil. A rich man (neighbor) follows the poor man’s example but confesses that he has slept, & so the devil takes his soul.
A man wants to marry a wife even if she comes from the devil. He gets a woman who had been carried off by the devil because of the careless words of her mother (“Go to the devil”).
An old woman curses a young boy (grandson) at his wedding & the devil carries him away. His wife goes after him & brings her husband back from the devil.
A man (farmer) perjures himself during a trial & exclaims, “May as many devils come as hairs are in my body & tear them out!” Thereupon the devils really come & tear out all his hair.

Classifications: The Devil Who Skins a Corpse
Variation Example: A poor man promises three times to hold a wake for a rich man. When the rich man dies, the poor man goes to the cemetery & draws a circle around himself. The devil appears, digs the grave up, takes the corpse out of the coffin, & skins it. While the devil puts the grave in order the poor man pulls the skin into his circle. The devil wants it back because he intended to wear it to haunt people. The poor man is able to delay by negotiating with the devil until the time of his wake has passed. The skin is buried again.

Classifications: Shoemaker Who Made Shoes for the Devil
Variation Example: A shoemaker (smith, tailor) is always cursing (unwisely boasts that he could shoe the devil’s own horse). He meets the devil (on his horse, disguised as a man) who asks him to make shoes for him (for his horse). Realizing that he is dealing with the devil, the shoemaker asks a clergyman for help. The clergyman advises him not to take (all) the money from the devil, because if he does, he will have sold his soul. A soon as the shoes are handed over, the devil, delighted, offers him a sum of money. But the shoemaker saves his soul by refusing it. (From that time he never curses again.)

clergyman overhears a conversation of devils (ravens) & learns that the devil (devils) in the shape of a woman is preparing to tempt the pope (bishop, priest) in Rome. He ties the devils together with some holy object (rosary, etc.) & has them carry him on a church door to Rome, where he warns the pope against falling victim to temptation by the devil in female shape. (He receives thanks.)

Classifications: Devil Leaves at Mention of God's name
Variation Example: This misc. type comprises different tales dealing with people who meet the devil in the shape of a person, an animal, or an object (they sell their soul to the devil). By mentioning the name of God, Christ, Virgin Mary, Allah or by saying a prayer or by using holy water, a crucifix, or other holy objects, the devil is made to vanish.
He performs severe penance but cannot bear to humble himself & bow before the altar.

A painter is ordered by his master (the king) to paint a portrait of the devil. As he has never seen the devil, he does not know how to paint him. Then the devil appears & assists by showing himself (the painter paints the picture in the steam-bath, he paints only single parts, the devil presents himself only one part at a time). The painter does not look at the finished portrait (may not look at it). When his master looks at it, he dies (all those in the palace who look at it are frightened & flee or die, the king does not die). In a German variant a rich farmer orders a poor painter to paint the devil & offers him his farm as payment. The painter is worried because he does not know what the devil looks like. On the third night his guardian angel appears & tells him he should close his eyes & paint single parts on a paper roll. Every section should be rolled up immediately. He should never look at it & should burn it after the farmer sees it. When the farmer looks at the painting, he dies, & the painter becomes the owner of the farm.

Classifications: The Devil as Substitute for Day Laborer at Mowing
Variation Example: The devil in the shape of a little old man (workman, hunter) assists a weak farmhand, who works as day laborer for a greedy nobleman, with the mowing (treshing). He does a wonderful job: he mows & threshes as never before & carries the whole harvest plus a bull on his back. When the noble man realizes that the workman must be the devil, the devil takes him to hell, & the day laborer becomes the owner of the whole harvest & the bull.

Classifications: The Devil Mows with a Magic Sickle
Variation Example: A poor old innkeeper works as a farmhand for a rich landlord. The malicious foreman abuses the workmen but especially the innkeeper who cannot mow as fast as the others. The devil comes to the innkeeper & offers to mow for him in his shape at the landlord’s farm. He would bring his own sickle. As the devil mows with his sickle, he follows the foreman. He mows faster than all other workmen & the foreman tries desperately to keep up with him. He exhausts himself & dies of overexertion (the devil takes his soul, wrings his neck). The devil gives his sickle to the old innkeeper, who becomes the best mower from then on.

An old woman (farmer) must have her haying done on a certain day (has a contract with the devil). A mysterious stranger appears & promises his help. He comes at the last moment & mows the whole crop in one day (and the woman is released from the contract with the devil).
The Devil as Advocate

An innocent man (in league with the devil, who once was kind to the devil) is accused of theft. The com-plainant swears by the devil that the man is guilty. The devil helps the accused by carrying the complainant (judge) out of the the court room (and thus repays the hospitality of the accused man.

Classifications: Devil's Trickery Seperates Married Couples & Friends
Variation Example: Misc. type. Devil is helped by old woman (witch) to create quarrel (murder) between couple.

A traveler (soldier, sailor, merchant, student) eats a meal of eggs in an inn & leaves without paying. Some years later when he returns to pay his debt, the innkeeper claims the value of all chickens that would have hatched from the eggs in the meantime. The traveler cannot (is not willing to) pay such an enormous sum, so the innkeeper brings the case to trial. The traveler meets a man (devil, farmer, shepherd, servant, wise man, lawyer, Gypsy, child) who offers to act for him as his lawyer. On the day of the trial the lawyer comes late & excuses himself by explaining that he was cooking beans (other seed) for planting. The judge states that cooked beans could not germinate, & the lawyer answers that chickens could not be hatched from boiled eggs. The case is rejected (the devil carries off the judge).

Classifications: The Devil as Host at Dinner
Variation Example: In heaven people can eat as much as they like, but in hell everyone’s arms are so long (the spoons have fathom-long handles) that the people cannot feed themselves. The greedy & selfish ones do not get anything to eat, but the unselfish people feed one another & have plenty of food.
